status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. The Boston Public Works takes very seriously the responsibility of coordinating proposed paving projects with proposed utility street cut work. . The City has identified 22 utility companies and other City departments who regularly perform street cut work. . No street is paved unless all 22 entities clear the street. In 2009 the Boston PWD created an online reservation system called the City Of Boston Utility Coordination Software (COBUCS). . No utility company, private contractor, site plan engineer, or City department can receive a permit without first entering the work into COBUCS. . COBUCS will inform whether the entry is in conflict with another entry. Since 2009 over 3000 times, COBUCS has alerted the City and Permittees of a potential conflict. The City either held off the paving, or coordinated the work to get done before paving took place. . That is 3000 less cuts on guaranteed streets. . What we can't coordinate is emergency repairs. That is exactly what happened on Bateswell St. National Grid activated an emergency permit for a grade 1 leak. . It is incredibly frustrating for this to happen. The City does charge the offending utility extra paving fees to compensate for the cost of cutting into a brand new street. . That work will probably take place later this year, or next year. The City does not want to do any permanent repairs of any recent street cut work until a minimum of 90 days or preferable the next construction season. . The City will monitor the temporary patch left behind by National Grid. For any questions please don't hesitate to contact me at the number provided below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works. Tel 617.635.4951. Fax 617.635.7498. Cell 617.840.2249. Backup Cell 617.438.8517.

Many out of state (read: not MA registered) cars parked on Park Drive between the Fenway MBTA stop and the intersection of Park Drive at Beacon St. (Audubon Circle). This is entirely due to the lack of any signage designating parking regulations. There are no resident permit parking only signs, or 2 hour parking signs, or any parking signs at all! Currently there are cars from ME, NH, NY, NJ, DC, CT....

The impact for me as a Boston resident who DOES pay for my registration and excise tax is utter frustration when I can't find a legal parking spot on my own block because of all the out of state cars. Many of them park for days on end, others just park for the proximity to Fenway Park. Either way it needs to change.

Thank you,
Greg Case
